data.title: Prague History Timeline - Important Dates & People
data.meta_description: Timeline of important dates and major events in the history of Prague. Illustrated list of events and people from our today in history archives.
data.text:
Prague History Timeline

Events in Prague History

Arnost of Pardubice becomes the first Archbishop of Prague (and the last bishop of Prague)

Prague University, first university in central Europe, formed by Charles IV

Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor assists laying the foundation stone of Charles Bridge in Prague

Jerome of Prague burned at the stake for heresy by church Council of Constance

First Defenestration of Prague: Anti-Catholic Hussites, followers of executed reformer Jan Hus, storm Prague Town Hall and throw the judge, mayor, and several city council members out the windows. They die in the fall or are killed by the crowd outside

Battle at Vitkov Zizka's hill (Prague): Taboriets beat Bohemia

The Battle of Lipany (also called the Battle of Česky Brod), ending Taborites influence

Jewish quarter of Prague burned and looted

Fleming Pieter Stevens appointed royal painter of Rudolf II (Prague)

Brahe and Kepler Meet

Astronomers Tycho Brahe and Johannes Kepler meet for the first time near Prague

Matthias von Habsburg's army reaches Lieben, at Prague

Second Defenestration of Prague: Two Catholic Lords Regent and their secretary are thrown out of a window and amazingly are not seriously injured by the 70 foot (21m) fall. Triggers the Thirty Years' War.

Battle of White Mountain, Prague - 1st major victory of the Catholic Habsburgs over the Protestant Alliance in The Thirty Years' War

Saxon army occupies Prague

Wallenstein Recaptures Prague

Albrecht von Wallenstein's Catholic League army recaptures Prague

Peace of Prague

The Peace of Prague signed between the Habsburg Emperor Ferdinand II and the Electorate of Saxony (representing Protestant states of the Holy Roman Empire). It effectively ended the civil war aspect of the Thirty Years' War

Last Swedish troops vacate Prague

The miraculous statue entitled the Infant of Prague is solemnly crowned by command of Cardinal Harrach

Maria Theresa crowned Queen of Bohemia in Prague

French & Beiers army occupies Prague

Austrian forces pillage & kill Jews of Prague

Jews are expelled from Prague

Battle of Prague: Frederick II of Prussia's forces defeat Austrian army

Empress Maria Theresa expels Jews from Prague, Bohemia and Moravia

Don Giovanni

Opera "Don Giovanni", music by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, libretto by Lorenzo Da Ponte premieres at the National Theater of Bohemia in Prague

Wolfgang Mozart's dramatic opera "La Clemenza di Tito" premieres at Estates Theatre, Prague

Doppler Effect

Christian Doppler presents his idea, now known as the Doppler Effect (through the changing colors of binary stars), to the Royal Bohemian Society, Prague

The Slavic congress in Prague begins.

Music Premiere

Bedřich Smetana's first opera "Branibori v Cechach" ("The Brandenburgers in Bohemia") premieres in Prague

Opera "Die Verkaufte Braut" premieres (Prague)

Treaty of Prague ends Austro-Prussian war

Bedřich Smetana's opera "Dalibor" premieres at the New Town Theatre in Prague

Franz Grillparzer's "Die Judin von Toledo" premieres in Prague

Bedřich Smetana's opera "Libuše" premieres iat the Natonal Theater, in Prague

1st photograph of a meteor taken by Austro-Hungarian photographer Ladislaus Weinek in Prague, Austrian-Hungarian Empire

Eugen d'Albert's opera "Tiefland" premieres in Prague

Sonata 1. X. 1905

František Pavlík is killed in a demonstration in Prague, inspiring Leoš Janáček to write his Piano Sonata 1. X. 1905.

Mahler's 7th Symphony

Gustav Mahler's 7th Symphony premieres in Prague, Austria-Hungary (now Czech Republic)

The Prague Party Conference takes place.

Event of Interest

Karel Čapek "Loupeznik" premieres in Prague

Karel Čapek's "Vec Makropulos" premieres in Prague

Karel Čapek's play "R.U.R." premieres in Prague, introduces the word "robot"

18th International Zionists Congress opens in Prague, Czechoslovakia

BBC's first feature film on TV (The Student of Prague)

Reinhard Heydrich

Reinhard Heydrich, "butcher of Prague," appointed SS-general (Gruppenfuehrer)

Attempted assassination of Nazi leader Reinhard Heydrich by a grenade thrown by Czech rebels in Prague during Operation Anthropoid; he dies a week later from an infection. Adolf Hitler orders 10,000 Czechs murdered in revenge, leads in June to the annihilation of Lidice.

Himmler in Prague

Reichsfuehrer Herman Himmler arrives in Prague

Bombing of Dresden

World War II: Prague is bombed probably due to a mistake in the orientation of the pilots bombing Dresden.

Uprising against occupying SS troops in Prague

Soviet troops occupied Prague

Concerto for Piano and Orchestra

Darius Milhaud's 3rd Concerto for Piano and Orchestra premieres in Prague

Prague espionage trial against bishops & priests begins

Trial against RC clergy "imperialistic conspiracy" begins in Prague

Plane crash kills entire US figure skating team outside Brussels airport in Belgium enroute to World Championships in Prague from NYC; 73 crew and passengers (including 34 American skaters, coaches, officials, and other team members), and a farmer on the ground are lost

Statue of Joseph Stalin in Prague is removed as part of de-Stalinzation efforts

Ballon d'Or: Dukler Prague midfielder Josef Masopust wins award for best European football player; beats Benfica striker Eusébio and FC Köln defender Karl-Heinz Schnellinger

Ludvik Vaculik publishes "Manifest of 2000 words" in Prague

"Manifest of 1000 words" published in Prague

Tito Visits Prague

Yugoslav president Tito visits Prague

Ceausescu Visits Prague

Romanian president Nicolae Ceausescu visits Prague

Warsaw Pact Invasion of Czechoslovakia

During the night, 250,000 Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops invade Czechoslovakia to put down the Prague Spring

Warsaw Pact of Czechoslovakia

Warsaw Pact forces complete their invasion of Czechoslovakia by arresting the Czech leader Alexander Dubček and forcing him to sign the Moscow Protocols

Zatopek "Public Enemy"

Once influential daily sports newspaper, 'Soviet Sport' declares Czech super-star distance runner Emil Zatopek a "public enemy" after he supports democratic wing of the Communist Party at start of the Prague Spring

Police break up a march by hundreds of demonstrators in central Prague

Ballon d'Or

Ballon d'Or: Bayern Munich defender Franz Beckenbauer wins title of Europe's best football player for a 2nd time; beats Anderlecht winger Rob Rensenbrink and Dukla Prague goalkeeper Ivo Viktor

Charter 77, a document criticising the Czech government's human rights abuses, is published in Prague

69th Davis Cup: Czechoslovakia beats Italy in Prague (4-1)

24th Tennis Fed Cup: USA beats Czechoslovakia in Prague Czech (3-0)

Football striker Mark Hughes plays for Wales and Bayern Munich in 2 countries on same day; appears for Wales in 2-0 European Championship loss to Czechoslovakia in Prague, then jets to Munich for 3-2 Cup win over Borussia

Dissident Havel Arrested

Czech dissident Václav Havel is arrested in Prague for taking part in demonstrations against the communist government

West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher grants escaping East Germans free passage to the West in speech from West German embassy balcony in Prague

Student demonstration in Prague put down by riot police, leading to an uprising (the Velvet Revolution) that will topple the communist government on Dec. 29

HCA, Helsinki Citizens Assembly, forms in Prague

Sports History

Men's Figure Skating Championship in Prague won by Kurt Browning CAN

Worlds Ladies' Figure Skating Championship in Prague won by Ukrainian Oksana Baiul

Ice Dance Championship in Prague won by M Usova & A Zhulin (RUS)

1993-03-19 Ice Pairs Championship in Prague won by I Brasseur & L Eisler (CAN)

Anti-globalization protests in Prague (some 20,000 protesters) turned violent during the IMF and World Bank summits.

Federation Cup Women's Tennis, Prague, Czech Republic: Lucie Šafářová beats Jelena Janković of Serbia 6-1, 6-1 to give the home team a 3-1 win in the final

101st Davis Cup: Czech Republic beats Spain in Prague (3-2)

Czech Republic vs. Germany

Federation Cup Women's Tennis, Prague, Czech Republic: Home favourite Petra Kvitová beats Germany's Angelique Kerber 7-6, 4-6, 6-4 for an unassailable 3-0 lead (ends 3-1) and an 8th title for the Czechs

Federation Cup Women's Tennis, Prague, Czech Republic: Czech pair Karolína Plíšková & Barbora Strýcová beats Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova & Elena Vesnina of Russia 4-6, 6-3, 6-2 for a 3-2 win and 9th title for the home country

Sports History

Laver Cup Men's Tennis, Prague: Roger Federer is unbeaten as Team Europe dominates Team World, 15-9 in the inaugural teams event

Federation Cup Women's Tennis, Prague, Czech Republic: in a final denuded of both countries' top players Kateřina Siniaková beats American Sofia Kenin 7-5, 5-7, 7-5 to clinch a 3-0 win for the home side

Event of Interest

Biggest protests in Prague since the fall of communism by tens of thousands against Prime Minister Andrej Babis' use of EU subsidies

Biggest protests in Prague since the fall of communism against Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis, with estimated 250,000 in Letna Plain park

Famous People from Prague

Birthdays 1 - 100 of 147

Wenceslaus II, King of Bohemia & Poland (1278-1305), born in Prague, Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1305)

Wenceslaus III of Bohemia, King of Hungary (1301-05) and King of Bohemia and Poland (1305-06), born in Prague, Czech Republic (d. 1306)

Arnost of Pardubice, Archbishop of Prague (d. 1364)

Catharine of Bohemia, Duchess of Bavaria, born in Prague, Bohemia (d. 1395)

Anne of Bohemia, Queen of England and wife of Richard II, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1394)

John Georg I, Elector of Saxony (1611-56, Peace of Prague), born in Dresden, Electorate of Saxony, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1656)

Václav [Wenceslaus] Hollar, Bohemian-born etcher (depictioned17th century London), born in Prague, Bohemia (d. 1677)

Prince Rupert of the Rhine, English-German soldier (Royalist Commander English Civil War, 1stt Governor of the Hudson's Bay Company), born in Prague (d. 1682)

František Maxmilián Kaňka, Czech architect and builder, born in Prague (d. 1766)

Kilian Ignaz Dientzenhofer, Czech Baroque architect (St. Nicholas Church, Prague), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1751)

Joseph Wenzel I, Prince of Liechtenstein and general, born in Prague (d. 1772)

Ferdinand Philipp Joseph Lobkowitz, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1784)

Josef Mysliveček, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1781)

Thomas Anton Kunz, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1830)

Alois Senefelder, German actor and inventor (lithography), born in Prague (d. 1834)

Jan Nepomuk Kanka, Czech composer, born in Prague Old Town, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1863)

Bernard Bolzano, Czech mathematician and philosopher, born in Prague, Bohemia (d. 1848)

Kaspar Masek, Czech-Slovenian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1873)

(Isaac) Ignaz Moscheles, Bohemian piano virtuoso, friend of Beethoven, teacher of Mendelssohn, conductor, and composer, born in Prague, Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1870) [1]

Josef Dessauer, Austrian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1876)

Albin Masek, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1878)

Zikmund Kolešovský, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1868)

Hans Hampel, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1884)

Wilhelm Kuhe, German composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1912)

Adolf Rzepko, Polish composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1892)

Eduard Hanslick, German music critic, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1904)

W. A. Remy [Wilhelm Mayer], Austro-Bohemian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1898)

Josef Richard Rozkošný, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1913)

Vilém Blodek [Plodek], Czech pianist, flautist, and composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1874)

Wilhelm Steinitz, Austrian World Chess Champion (1866-94), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austrian Empire (d. 1900)

Karel Bendl, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1897)

Prince Alfred, Liechtenstein noble and politician, born in Prague, Czech Republic (d. 1907)

Prince Louis of Liechtenstein, Liechtenstein nobleman and politician, born in Prague (d. 1920)

Karel Komzák II, Bohemian-Viennese violinist, and composer of marches and dances (Bad’ner Mad’ln), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1905) [1]

Victor Adler, Austrian politician (Minister of Foreign Affairs), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austrian Empire (d. 1918)

Joseph Miroslav Weber, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia, Austrian Empire (d. 1906)

František Ondříček, Czech violinist and composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1922)

Josef Bohuslav Foerster, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1951)

Karel Weis, Czech composer and folk song collector, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1944)

Karel Kovařovic, Czech harpist, conductor (Prague National Theatre, 1900-20), and composer (The Dogheads), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1920)

Richard Batka, Austrian music critic and composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1922)

Olga Engl, Austrian actress (Phantom), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1946)

Julius Fučík, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1916)

Olga Fastrová, Czech writer and editor (National Policy), born in Prague (d. 1965)

Hans Eppinger, Austrian physician, born in Prague, Czech Republic (d. 1946)

Rudolf Friml, Czech-American concert pianist and composer (Rose-Marie; The Vagabond King), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1972)

Hans Kelsen, Austrian legal philosopher and political philosopher, born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1973)

Vaclav Klicka, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1953)

Leo Perutz, Austrian writer and mathematician, born in Prague (d. 1957)

Jaroslav Hašek, Czech writer (The Good Soldier Švejk), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 1923)

Franz Kafka

Czech author (Metamorphosis, Trial, Amerika), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary

Max Brod, Czech-born Israeli composer, writer, and biographer of Kafka, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1968)

Egon Kisch, Austrian-Czech writer and journalist (Rasende Reporter), born in Prague (d. 1948)

János Hammerschlag, Hungarian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1954)

Otto Lederer, Austrian actor (The Jazz Singer), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 1965)

Jan Masaryk, Czech statesman and Minister to London (1918-35), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 1948)

Jim Thorpe

American all-round athlete (Olympic gold decathlon, pentathlon 1912; College & Pro Football Hall of Fame), born in Indian Territory, Oklahoma

Joseph Beran, Czech Roman Catholic prelate, born in Pilsen, Czech Republic (d. 1969)

Paul Kornfeld, Czech playwright, born in Prague (d. 1942)

Franz Werfel, Austrian-Bohemian novelist, playwright, and poet (Mirror Man, The Forty Days of Musa Dagh), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 1945)

Ernst Deutsch [Dorian], Jewish-Austrian actor (Moon is Down, 3rd Man), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1969)

Jan Evangelista Zelinka, Czech composer (Meluzina), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1969)

Erwin Schulhoff, Czech-Russian composer and pianist (Ogelala) who died in a German concentration camp, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1942) [1]

Pavel Bořkovec, Czech composer (Suite for Piano), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1972)

Jaromir Weinberger, Czech-American composer (Bird's Opera), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1967)

John Urzidil, Austrian-American writer (Die erbeuteten Frauen), born in Prague (d. 1970)

Carl Ferdinand Cori, Czech-American bio-chemist (Nobel 1947-discovery of how glycogen (animal starch) – a derivative of glucose – is broken down and resynthesized in the body, for use as a store and source of energy), born in Prague (d. 1984)

František Tomášek, 34th Archbishop of Prague and cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church in Bohemia, born in Studénka, Austria-Hungary (d. 1992)

Franz C. Schmelkes, Czech-born Chemist who discovered azochloramid (chlorazodin), widely used as a disinfectant to sterilize wounds and burns, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1942)

Iša Krejčí, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1968)

Vladimír Holan, Czech poet, born in Prague, Czech Republic (d. 1980)

Jaroslav Ježek, Czechoslovakian composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1942)

Francis Lederer, Czech actor (Diary of a Chambermaid), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2000)

George Schick, Czech conductor (Chicago Symphony, 1950-56; Metropolitan Opera, 1958-69), and educator, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1985)

Karel Ančerl, Czechoslovak conductor (Czech Philharmonic, 1950-68; Toronto Symphony, 1968-73), composer, and Auschwitz survivor, born in Tučapy, Czech Republic (d. 1973)

Miloslav Kabeláč, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1979)

H. G. Adler, Czech-English writer (The Journey; Theresienstadt 1941-1945), Holocaust survivor. and poet, born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1988)

Frank Pelleg [Pollack], Czech-Israeli harpsichordist, pianist, conductor and educator, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1968) [1]

Vit Nejedly, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1945)

Walter Susskind, Czech conductor and pianist, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1980)

Jan Kapr, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1988)

Lída Baarová [Ludmila Babková], Czech actress (Die Fledermaus, Virginity), born in Prague, Bohemia, Austria-Hungary (d. 2000)

Jan Hanus, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 2004)

Jan Rychlik, Czech composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (d. 1964)

George Pravda, Austria-Hungary, actor (Thunderball, Firefox), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1985)

Herbert Lom, Czech-born British actor (Pink Panther, Dorian Gray), born in Prague, Austria-Hungary (d. 2012)

Vera Ralston [Věra Helena Hrubá], Czech figure skater and actress (Dakota, Accused of Murder), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2003)

Karel Husa, Czech-American Pulitzer prize winning composer (Trojan Women), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2016)

Jaroslav Drobný

Czech ice hockey player (Olympic silver 1948) and tennis player (Wimbledon 1954, French Open 1951-52), born in Prague, Czech Republic

Ladislav Fuks, Czech writer, born in Prague (d. 1994)

Miloslav Kříž, Czech basketball coach (Czech Women's team, German Men's team), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2013)

Jindřich Feld, Czech composer (Concerto for Flute and Orchestra), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2007)

Ivan Jirko, Czech composer, music critic and psychiatrist, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1978)

Jan Křesadlo, Czech-British psychologist and writer, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1995)

Václav Felix, Czech composer, and pedagogue, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2008)

Pavel Kohout, Czech-Austrian playwright (Poor Murderer), poet, novelist (I Am Snowing), and dissident (Charter 77), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia

Zdeněk Lukáš, Czech composer, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2007)

Josef Suk, Czech concert violinist (Artist of Merit, 1977), violist, and namesake of composer grandfather, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 2011)

Vladimír Škutina, Czechoslovakian writer and actor (Hvezda jede na jih), born in Prague, Czechoslovakia (d. 1995)
